contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of that day and night as if they were people. Alternate translation: "I wish that I had never been born" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: May the day on which I was born perish, the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the night is spoken of as if it were a person who could speak. The translator may choose, however, to translate it in a less metaphorical way. Alternate translation: "the night about which people said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the night that said

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here darkness and the shadow of death are spoken of as if they were people who could claim something as their own possession. The word "it" refers to the day of Job's birth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: May darkness and the shadow of death claim it for their own

contextId.occurrenceNote: "terrify that day." The day is spoken of as if it were a person who could be terrified by the darkness. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: terrify it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This darkness is again spoken of as if it were a person who could grasp and hold the night. Alternate translation: "may thick darkness make it disappear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: may thick darkness seize it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "it" refers to the night of Job's birth or conception. The night of Job's conception is spoken of as if it were a person who should not rejoice. Alternate translation: "May that night vanish from the calendar" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: May it not rejoice

contextId.occurrenceNote: That night is spoken of as if it were a person who could walk. Alternate translation: "may no one count it in the number" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: may it not come into the number

contextId.occurrenceNote: The night of Job's birth is spoken of as if it were a woman. Alternate translation: "may no child be born on that night" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: may that night be barren

contextId.occurrenceNote: The day of Job's birth is spoken of as if it were a person looking for something. Alternate translation: "May that day hope for light, but have none" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: May that day look for light, but find none

contextId.occurrenceNote: The dawn is spoken of as if it had eyelids as a person has. Alternate translation: "nor see the first light of the dawn" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: neither may it see the eyelids of the dawn

contextId.occurrenceNote: The day of Job's birth is spoken of here as if it were a person who could hide something. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: because it did not hide trouble from my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who say unjust things are spoken of as if they were the injustice itself, who must stop speaking. Alternate translation: "It is as though injustice shut her own mouth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: injustice shuts her own mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the terrible things that have happened to him as if they were soldiers that God had lined up to attack him all at once. Alternate translation: "God has caused all the terrible things that could happen to happen to me all at once" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the terrors of God have arranged themselves in array against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the snow melting and the water going into the streambed as if the snow were hiding in the streambed. Alternate translation: "because the snow melts and goes into them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: because of the snow that hides itself in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The garden is spoken of as if it had human ability to speak. The garden immediately forgets that he existed. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that place will deny him and say, 'I never saw you.'

contextId.occurrenceNote: This pictures the days of Job's life as being able to run away like a person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: my days flee away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This pictures the days of Job's life as being able to see like a person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: they see no good anywhere

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job's clothing is spoken of as if it would have a negative response to Job after God plunged him into a ditch. Alternate translation: "I would be too filthy for my own clothing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: my own clothes would be disgusted with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Unrighteousness living represents people doing unrighteous things. Alternate translation: "and you did not allow the members of your household to do unrighteous things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: did not let unrighteousness live in your tents

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the dead stump as if it could smell water to represent water being near it. Alternate translation: "even if only a little water is near it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: even if it only smells water

contextId.occurrenceNote: The tree sending out branches represents branches growing on the tree. Alternate translation: "branches will start growing on it like a plant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: send out branches like a plant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes "iniquity" as if it were a teacher and Job's mouth is described as if it is learning. This means that his speech is greatly influenced by his iniquity. Alternate translation: "your iniquity is like a teacher and your mouth is like its student" or "it is because of your sin that you speak the way you do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your iniquity teaches your mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job describes the shriveling of his body as if it were an accuser against him. Alternate translation: "and people think that shows me to be a sinner" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: which itself is a witness against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job describes the thinness of his body as if it were accuser against him. Alternate translation: "They see how thin my body is, and they think that proves that I am guilty" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the leanness of my body rises up against me, and it testifies against

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of wanting everyone to know what happened to him as if his "cry" were a person that never stopped testifying to what happened to him and never rested. Alternate translation: "let everyone hear about what has happened to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: let my cry have no resting place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase describes "the grave" as if it is a person who will receive Job as a guest. Alternate translation: "soon I will be dead and buried" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the grave is ready for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the things that terrify the wicked person as if they were enemies who chased him. Alternate translation: "it will be as if the terrors will chase him all around" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: they will chase him at his heels

contextId.occurrenceNote: This "spirit" or thought is spoken of as if it were a person that could answer Zophar. Alternate translation: "I have a thought from my understanding, and now I know what I wanted to know" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: a spirit from my understanding answers me

contextId.occurrenceNote: People thought of heaven or the sky as resting on pillars. Job speaks as though the pillars are humans that shake in fear when God is angry. Alternate translation: "The pillars that hold up heaven shake in fear when God rebukes them" or "The pillars that hold up the sky shake like people who are afraid when God rebukes them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: The pillars of heaven tremble and are astonished at his rebuke

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of the wind blowing the wicked man out of his house as if the wind were a person sweeping dust out of a house with a broom. Alternate translation: "the wind sweeps him out of his place like a woman who sweeps dirt out of a house" or "the wind easily blows him out of his place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: it sweeps him out of his place

contextId.occurrenceNote: In verses 22-23 Job speaks of the wind as if it were a person attacking the wicked person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the phrase "throws itself at him" represents the wind blowing strong against him like an attacker. Alternate translation: "It blows strong against him like someone attacking him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: It throws itself at him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" represents the power or control that the wind has over the wicked man. Alternate translation: "he tries to flee out of its control" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: he tries to flee out of its hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The foot is spoken of as if it is a person who can remember. Alternate translation: "places where people no longer walk" or "where no one ever walks" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: places that are forgotten by anyone's foot

contextId.occurrenceNote: The deep waters and the sea are presented as if they are people that can speak. Alternate translation: "Wisdom is not in the deep waters under the earth, nor is it in the sea" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: The deep waters ... say, 'It is not in me'; the sea says, 'It is not with me.'

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Destruction" and "Death" are spoken of as if they are living things who can speak. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Destruction and Death say

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his continuous suffering as if the days of suffering have grabbed hold of him. Alternate translation: "I suffer many days, and the suffering does not end" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: many days of suffering have laid hold on me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his constant pain as if it were alive and biting him and refuses to rest. Alternate translation: "the pains that cause me to suffer do not stop" or "I am in constant pain" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the pains that gnaw at me take no rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of his heart as if it were a person. Alternate translation: "I am troubled in my heart and the feeling does not end" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: My heart is troubled and does not rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "walking" represents moving slowly. Alternate translation: "the moon moving across the sky" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the moon walking

contextId.occurrenceNote: Job speaks of being guilty as if his land were a person who cries out against Job because of the wrong Job has done to the land. Alternate translation: "If I have done wrong concerning my land" or "If I have stolen my land from someone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: If my land ever cries out against me, and its furrows weep together

contextId.occurrenceNote: Elihu speaks of God judging Job and giving him justice as if judgment and justice were people that have laid hold of Job. Alternate translation: "God has brought you to judgment and given you justice" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: judgment and justice have laid hold of you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The morning stars are spoken of as singing like people sing. Possible meanings are: 1) the "morning stars" are the same as the "sons of God" in the next line or 2) "the morning stars" refer to stars in the sky. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: when the morning stars sang together

contextId.occurrenceNote: "when I said to the sea." Yahweh speaks to the sea as though it were a person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: when I said to it

contextId.occurrenceNote: "to the power of your waves." The waves are spoken of as if they could have pride. The abstract noun "pride" can be translated as the adjective "proud." Alternate translation: "to your proud waves" or "to your powerful waves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: to the pride of your waves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes the morning as being able to receive orders and know things like a person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: given orders to the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: "the dwelling of light." Light is spoken of as having a resting place from which it comes forth each day. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the resting place of light

contextId.occurrenceNote: "to their territory." Light and darkness are spoken of as being led out and back each day to accomplish Yahweh's purposes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: to their places of work

contextId.occurrenceNote: The waters are spoken of as being able to hide. During the winter the ice hides the water underneath it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rpronouns]])
contextId.glQuote: The waters hide themselves and become like stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: The lightning bolts are spoken of as servants saying they are ready to follow commands. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Here we are

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes the donkey as though he were a person that had a house. "I gave him the Arabah as a place to live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: whose home I have made in the Arabah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh describes the donkey as though he were a person. The donkey laughs because those in the city have to hear loud noise, but he lives in a quiet place. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: laughs in scorn

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "Aha" is a sound people make when they discover something. The horse makes a sound because he has discovered the battle. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: he says, 'Aha

contextId.occurrenceNote: The hills are spoken of as if they were people capable of giving him food. Alternate translation: "food grows on the hills for him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: the hills provide him with food

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person throwing the spear hopes that the spear will kill Leviathan, but the writer speaks as if Leviathan knows the spear will not kill him and so laughs. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: he laughs at the whirring flight of a spear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Leviathan is spoken of as if he were a person who is able to become king and be proud. Alternate translation: "Leviathan has more reason to be proud than anyone else on earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: he is king over all the sons of pride
